title.narrative: USAID Child Blindness Program, Narayani Zone (NZ) Pediatric Eye Program

description.narrative:
For 37 years, Seva Foundation has worked to prevent and treat unnecessary blindness in Nepal through the development of high-quality, locally-run eye care programs. With support from USAID and donor organizations, Seva established a successful pediatric eye care program at the Lumbini Eye Institute (LEI) where they serve over 24,000 children per year, including 1,200 eye surgeries. Based on years of service, Seva recognizes the need to replicate successful pediatric programming at LEI- highly underserved Narayani Zone (NZ) of Central Nepal with the population of 2.3 million.
Seva’s “NZ Pediatric Eye Care Program” proposes to improve and scale up the delivery of sustainable pediatric eye care services amongst three NZ partnership eye hospitals and eight Primary Eye Care Centers in order to reduce avoidable blindness in children by: 1) improving training of eye care and health practitioners; 2) Coordinating among health facilities to optimize use of ophthalmologists through telemedicine and scheduled site visits; 3) Expanding community education and outreach programs both for early detection and follow-up care; 4) increasing access to services for children by reducing geographic and socioeconomic barriers.

The NZ Pediatric Eye Program will aim to provide at least 300,000 eye exams, 25,000 medical treatments, 8,000 eyeglasses and 840 sight-restoring eye surgeries over two years to children who would otherwise remain visually impaired or blind. The program will endeavor to find, treat and follow-up with vulnerable, poor, rural and female children.
Expected Outcomes: During the two-year project period, the NZ Pediatric Eye Program will train 21 pediatric eye care personnel and 4,800 community health partners. The project will provide 100,000 eye exams at partner sites, 200,000 eye exams in schools, 840 eye surgeries, 8,000 glasses, and 25,000 medical treatments. We will increase follow-up examinations after surgery by 50% and expect to see 10% more female patients than baseline.
